Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating Gene Networks Regulating Development in Tomato
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Neelima R. Sinha (University of California, Davis)
CoPI: Julin Maloof (University of California, Davis)
CoPI: Jie Peng (University of California, Davis)

Plants acquire the bulk of their energy from light capture by leaves, and leaf shape has direct consequences on the efficiency of light capture and photosynthetic carbon fixation. As a result, leaf shape must be optimized in response to variation in light quality. To understand the processes controlling these fundamental processes, genetic networks regulating both environmental response and morphological form must be integrated. This project uses a genomics approach to understand natural variation in leaf morphology and light response, and to investigate the mechanism by which these two genetic networks are integrated to ensure optimal plant form. These goals will be accomplished by characterizing the differences between tomato species varying in both light response and leaf complexity. Characterization of these differences will be made using genomic technologies to find differences in DNA sequence and gene expression. Statistical analyses will be used to reconstruct the web of interacting genes (genetic networks) that regulate leaf morphology and light responses. This analysis will allow identification of central regulators of development and developmental variation. Increased knowledge of the basis of phenotypic diversity in the developmental and environmental context should allow better manipulation of crop systems for improved agricultural productivity. Finally, a program will be developed to train future researchers and students from under-represented groups from UC Davis, Cal State University Sacramento, and Los Rios Community College in modern cross-disciplinary genomic biology.

All data, gene chip data, BIN maps, QTL analysis and networks generated by this project will be made available to the public as soon as the data has passed quality control. All Solexa sequence data will be deposited in Genbank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Genbank/). All microarray data will be deposited in the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/). In addition, community specific data will be made available via the SOLGENES website (http://www.sgn.cornell.edu/) and a project-specific web site that will be developed.

Plants acquire the bulk of their energy from light capture by leaves, and leaf shape has direct consequences on the efficiency of light capture and photosynthetic carbon fixation. As a result, leaf shape must be optimized in response to variation in light quality. To understand the genetic programs controlling fundamental developmental processes, genetic networks regulating both environmental response and morphological form must be integrated. We used a genomics approach to understand natural variation in leaf morphology and light response, and to investigate the mechanism by which these two genetic networks are integrated to ensure optimal developmental pattern in tomato, its wild relatives and set of introgression lines (ILs) generated by crossing one of the wild relatives to tomato.

 

Project Outcomes:

We used deep sequencing of the parent mRNAs to identify changes in both gene sequence and expression levels. Comparing the parental mRNA profiles allowed to determine how human selection has shaped the tomato genome. The IL population was densely phenotyped for leaf development and light-response traits and also for mRNA levels. These expression patterns were used in construction of genetic networks regulating leaf morphology and light development and to identify central regulators of development and developmental variation. We generated markers that can be used in tomato breeding, and also identified leaf shapes that could be predictors of fruit quality in tomato. We trained over 20 community college students in scientific research methods.

 

Practical Applications of Research:

Agricultural productivity is the result of light capture and carbon fixation by leaves. Allocation of the fixed carbon at the developmental level is regulated by light quality as perceived through the phytochrome photoreceptors. Light quality both regulates carbon allocation and modulates plant development. Particularly important in determining photosynthetic function are features of leaf complexity and anatomy. By constructing gene regulatory networks governing leaf development and light response, our research has provided better understanding of how these processes and morphologies are regulated by genes and environmental inputs. Increased knowledge of the basis of phenotypic diversity in the developmental and environmental context will allow better manipulation of crop systems for improved agricultural productivity. In addition, wild tomato species can be the source of many important agricultural traits.  The tools, techniques, and markers developed here will help breeders exploit wild tomato diversity for crop improvement.
